list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: No-one can be spared from this office.

list_definition.definition: to afford or set aside for a purpose

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I can’t spare the time for a holiday.

list_definition.definition: to treat with mercy; to avoid injuring etc
to avoid causing grief, trouble etc to (a person)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Break the news gently in order to spare her as much as possible.
He spared no expense in his desire to help us.

list_definition.definition: to avoid troubling (a person with something); to save (a person trouble etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I answered the letter myself in order to spare you the bother.
We haven’t a spare (bed) room for guests in our house.

list_definition.definition: (of time etc) free for leisure etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: What do you do in your spare time?

list_definition.definition: a spare part (for a car etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: They sell spares at that garage.

list_definition.definition: an extra wheel etc, kept for emergencies.

list_ex_of_english: Everyone has organs to spare, whether dead or living.
The system is linked to the illustrated spare parts catalogue and to relevant electronics technical documentation.
It assumes all dialysis machines are available for use and none are under repair, kept as spare, or dedicated for high-risk patients.
In principle, this can spare remaining forests from conversion to crop land.
The addresses are rarely those of farmers because more often than not they concern spare time breeders.
Some of his examples really involve a tripartite division (=triglossia) such as thin spare emaciated.
Women, particularly the unsuccessfully treated, wanted babies of their own to rear and often spent much of their spare time baby-sitting.
The reduction in the number of fractions spares resources and this may help to reduce waiting times, another factor in local tumour control.
